If it is 1 in an infinite limit you end up with a situation call “almost certain” A “certain" event is where all possible combinations lead to this outcome. “Almost certain" is where the probability approaches 1, but it can never quite get there. “Almost never" is an equivalent event when the probability goes to 0. A good example. The probability of flipping nothing but heads when you flip a coin N times is (1/2)^N. If you look at this the larger N is the closer to 0 it gets. In the infinite limit the probability becomes 0. However it's not truly impossible to get an infinite sequence of nothing but head flips. It still exists and still is possible, just infinitely unlikely. It's more a consequence of the fact that probability when you are dealing with infinite possibilities doesn't act like probability when you have only a finite number of outcomes.

happen? The probability of an event is a number describing the chance that the event will happen. An event that is certain to happen has a probability of 1 . But probability does not guarantee “when” it will happen. Give you an example, human dies some day, the probability of such event is 1, but no one will guarantee “when” it will happen.
